description.short: Open-access repository of 2+ million scholarly articles in physics, mathematics, computer science, AI/ML, and related fields
description.detailed: arXiv is a free distribution service and open-access archive for scholarly articles in the fields of physics, mathematics, computer science, quantitative biology, quantitative finance, statistics, electrical engineering and systems science, and economics. Founded in 1991, it has become the primary pre-print repository for AI/ML research, allowing researchers to share findings before formal peer review. Papers receive arXiv IDs (e.g., 2301.12345) and are searchable by category, author, title, and abstract.
description.primary_function: Repository and discovery platform for cutting-edge research papers, especially AI/ML pre-prints
key_capabilities: Daily uploads of new pre-prints (1000+ papers/day in cs.AI alone)
Search by category, keyword, author, or arXiv ID
Email alerts for new papers in specific categories
Free, unrestricted access to all content

use_cases.description: Search for recent papers on specific techniques (e.g., 'vision transformers', 'retrieval augmented generation') to find cutting-edge approaches
use_cases.user_persona: ML engineers, PhD students, research scientists

use_cases.user_persona: Research teams, product strategists, PhD students

use_cases.title: Verify Claims in Technical Discussions
use_cases.description: Look up cited papers by arXiv ID to verify methodology, results, and conclusions during technical debates

core_features.description: Browse papers by subject area (cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.CV, stat.ML, etc.)
Search by title, author, abstract, comments, journal reference, subject category, or report number
Subscribe to daily or weekly digests of new papers in specific categories
Download LaTeX source files in addition to PDFs
Track revisions to papers (v1, v2, v3) as authors update based on feedback
Export citations in BibTeX, EndNote, and other formats

efficiency_gains: 90% faster access to pre-prints vs. traditional publication cycles

roi_metrics.value_proposition: Essential tool for anyone working in AI/ML to stay current with rapidly evolving research landscape

setup_recommendations: Subscribe to 2-3 core categories relevant to your work (start narrow, expand later)
Set up email alerts for daily digest (morning reading routine)
Create Dropbox Dash Stack for specific research topics
Use RSS reader for category feeds if you prefer that workflow
Bookmark frequent search queries for quick access
usage_patterns: Skim abstracts first, read papers selectively (10:1 skim-to-read ratio)
Check 'recent' papers (last 7 days) for your categories 2-3x per week
Follow citation trails for foundational papers
Use arXiv ID in documentation/discussions for precise references
Combine with Semantic Scholar or Connected Papers for context
Download PDFs for offline reading during commute/travel
time_management: Allocate 30-60 minutes 3x per week for paper review
Use 'two-pass' reading: abstract → conclusion → methods (if still relevant)
Maintain a 'to read deeply' list (max 5 papers at a time)
Share interesting findings with team via Slack/email to distribute effort

known_limitations: No built-in recommendation engine (manual search required)
Search can be overwhelming (100+ new cs.AI papers per day)
No native PDF annotation or note-taking features
Limited metadata (no code/data links in many papers)
limitations.best_for: Researchers, engineers, students in technical fields with active arXiv communities
limitations.not_ideal_for: Applied fields without strong arXiv presence (e.g., medicine, law, business)
